div1.p: In the District Court of the United States, for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division
In the matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, aliens, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus | #2628 Petitioners' reply brief
Argument

We shall take but little issue with counsel for the Government, upon the "RULE" and the "REASONS FOR THE RULE", bu which the Court is limited in this sort of proceeding, to the one question of whether or not the petitioners had a fair and legal hearing; and if so, whether there is, in the record, any evidence to sustain the charge.

(a) There must be some definite and specific offense charged, bringing the alien within the excluded class, in order that he may have an opportunity to meet it upon the Government warrant to show cause why he should not be deported;
(b) There must be a hearing on that specific charge:
(c) There must be some evidence adduced which amounts to legal evidence, tending to prove this specific charge;

(d) There must be a finding by the proper authorities, which finding, in order to be legitimate and sufficient, must be based on and fairly deducible from this evidence. A finding which is clearly arbitrary, that is not fairly deducible from such evidence, that is based, rather, upon the opinion of some Inspector or other official, 1
to the exclusion or in disregard of the evidence or one which is arrived at by reason of extraneous circumstances arising subsequent to such hearing, or upon findings based upon some alleged offense other than the one charged in the orginial Warrant, cannot be sustained as a fair and legal hearing; and if such is the case here, it is the duty of the Court to sustain the Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Our contention here is that the petitioners did not have a fair and legal hearing for the following reasons:

1. The Warrant of Arrest, which reads as follows: "Warrant - Arrest of Aliens That the said aliens are unlawfully within the United States in that they have been found assisting, protecting, or promising to protect from arrest, a prostitute or prostitutes." does not definitely charge them with any specific act amount to a violation of the Immigration Act.

2. The Warrant for Deportation, which reads as follows: "Warrant - Deportation of Alien That the said aliens are unlawfully within the United States, in that they have been found assisting a prostitute and protecting or promising to protect from arrest, a prostitute, and may be deported in accordance therewith." does not find them guilty of any specific act amounting to a violation of the Act.
3. There was and if absolutely no evidence in the record what-ever, which can be regarded as legal evidence, tending to prove them guilty of the violation attempted to be charged.

4. The postion now taken by counsel for the Government in his Brief, and which was announced by him for the first time at the hearing on this Habeas Corpus, and which is evidently based upon the letter of opinion of Mr. J.B. Denamore, Solicitor, appended to and 2
as a part of his Brief, not only takes us by surprise, but is clearly a subsequent idea, and is an adroit and desperate effort, after failing on the first, to convict petitioners in some other offense than that in the original Warrant, upon which the hearing was had.
In United States v. Sibray, 178 Fed. pp. 148 and 149,l the Court says:

"I am constrained to hold that the charge is not sufficiently specific. It is not required that the warrant of arrest should have the formality and particularity of an indictment, but it should give to the alien sufficient information of the specific act or acts which bring him within the excluded classes, so that he can offer testimony in refutation of the charge at the hearing directed to be had by the warrant of arrest in pursuance of the act of Congress and the rules of the department. What woman is he charged with importing and for what immoral purpose? Was he convicted of or did he admit the commission of a crime? Was it a felony or other crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude? If either, which was it? By paragraph "b", Rule 35, as has been seen, a fully statement of the facts must be the basis of the warrant. It is contemplated therefore, that facts, and not conclusions, must be set forth in the warrant.
The hearing provided for should be according to established precedent, because that is contemplated by the act and regualtions.
There is no finding that any particular felony, crime, or misdemanor prior to entry was admitted.

I have gone over the testimony taken by the inspector, and do not find any evidence that the relator was convicted of or admits the commission of any offense which can be embraced within the general language of the warrants."

Then can be no doubt, from an inspection of the record, that the said hearing on the Warrant of Arrest was solely and only upon the theory that petitioners had rendered assistance and protection to some prostitute in avoiding arrest. There never was any other idea or charge, either inferentially or otherwise, and no other evidence adduced, than on this one ground. The very letter of information 3
of Thos. M. Fisher, Inspector (see record) recommending this arrest clearly shows this one idea and intention; he says:

"In the view of the facts above mentioned, it would seem to me that noth of these parties are subject to deportation, on the ground that they assisted a prostitute and promised to protect her from arrest."

The charge in the Warrant of Arrest and in the Warrant of Deportation and all the evidence adduced thereon, clearly indicate this one charge of assisting a prostitute from arrest (see also,k letter of Ellis de Bruler, Commissioner of Immigration, to the Commissioner General, dated November 11, 1913, on thee lower third of page 2 thereof), which reads as follows:
He thus refers to the evidence of Ito and Umeda on this point only.

The announcement of counsel for the Government at the hearing of the Habeas Corpus, coming, as it did, frankly and voluntarily, that he had carefully searched through the record in the Immigration proceeding in this case, and failed to find an evidence upon which the Warrant for Deportation could properly be based upon said ground of assisting from arrest, was not a surprise to us, because, we likewise, were unable to find any such evidence. But the subsequent announcement of councel, raising for the first time in this Habeas Corpus proceeding, the question of construction or meaning of the words, "who in any way assists", as used in the Immigration Act and Warrant of Arrest and for Deportation, claiming that said words were not to be construed with the rest of the setence in which they are used, but that Congress really meant and intended to carve out another offense, and provide against the same, than that of assisting from arrest, came as a complete surprise to us, and is clearly an effort 4
now to bolster up a failing cause, and catch the aliens upon some other charge still more indefinite than the first, and upon which they have not had a hearing.
If this is not a demonstration of arbitrary power and of findings upon charges never made and never proven, we can hardly conceive how it may more strongly appear.

This, however, being now the announced postition of the Government in this case, we take it that our attention and Brief need be directed only to the question of construction and meaning of said words.

At the very outset it seems to us the Government's contention in this second position is less tenable than in the first, for the reason that said words "any assistance" necessarily must be limited to any assistance of a prostitute in connection with her avocation. Mr.Denamore's said opinion concedes this much. Surely no Court could ever construe the meaning of Congress so as to subject an alien to deportation for assisting a fallen woman to reform, or to some more noble purpose.

We think that Congress did not intend to carve out or set apart a separate and distinct offense in the Immigration Act, by the use of the words, "who in any way assists"; but that the same were to be construed as a part and connected with and expressed in the rest of the sentence where they occur.

36 Cyc, page 1118 (g), Associate Words, says: "In accordance with the maxim, "noscitur a sociis", the meaning of a word used in a statute must be construed in connection with the words with which it is associated."

We think a careful reading of the entire section of the Immigration Act sustains our contention. Had there not already been a provision in the upper portion of this clause same statute providing for other 5
assistance of prostitutes there might be some remote probability that Congress intended the meaning ascribed by counsel. But in reading the entire section, the Court will see that their interpretation is far-fetched, and is a repetition of provisions already made. In the following words above:
"Any Alien ++++ who in any way assists a prostitute in the conduct of her avocation",etc.

Mr. Denamore says that the use of these words in connection with the rest of the sentence makes "bad English". But we claim that to use them in the sense counsel contends, would not only make "bad English" but would be bad law, and bad punctuation, and worse than allo, would be indefinite and absolutely meaningless, in failing to say what sort of assistance should render the alien liable.
The Court, in the case of People vs. Chicago, 152 Ill. pp. 546-552 (38 N. E. p.746), cited by counsel, says:

"When the literal enforcement of a statute would result in great inconvience and consequent injustice, and lead to consequences which are absurd, and which the legislature could not have contemplated, the Courts are bound to presume that such consequences are not intended, and adopt a construction which will promote the ends of justice, and avoid the absurdity."

Could anything be more absurd or unjust than to say that Congress intended to punish an lien with deportation, or condemn him as unworthy to remain in this country who "in any way assists" a prostitute to reform, or to get legitimate employment, or if he should find her destitute, or sick, or injured in the streets, and should aid her, etc?

In other words, even if the Court feels constrained to adopt the Government's view of the meaning of the aforesaid words, it cannot find any other reasonable meaning then that it was meant to prevent any assistance of a prostitute in the conduct or her avocation. And if this construction is now, at this late date, to be injected, then we contend with still greater earnestness, that the aliens have been denied a fair hearing upon this point for the following reasons:
2. If the Warrant for Arrest did not intend to charge them with assisting a prostitute to avoid arrest, then what did it intend to charge?
3. There was no specific charge in the Warrant of any other assistance, and the view now taken by counsel shows it;
4. If there was specific charge, then there could have been no specific finding in the Warrant for Deportation;

5. And if no specific charge, the evidence is all to no definite purpose and cannot be said to apply to anything. This is not a case where the pleadings may be amended to conform to the evidence. Hence, it is the same thing as no evidence.

The Government totally failed in establishing any evidence upon the theory that the aliens assisted or protected a prostitute 7
from arrest, which counsel voluntarily admitted in open Court. Therefore, we will not pursue this branch of the case further.

And assuming, for the sake of the argument only, that the Act should be construed as counsel contends, let us ask: where is there any evidence in the record in this case, that Young and Sugiura gave any assistance to the woman, Hana Saito, even in the way of her avocation as a prostitute? In her affidavit she herself says that she considered herself under arrest by Young and Sgiura. In this affidavit she says that she is testifying substantially as she did at the trial in the Federal Court. And yet, it appears by Young's statement (see page 7 of the record, and statement of Bertha Deadrich her affidavit, page 2,) that Hana testified in said first trial that when Young and Sugiura came to Tacoma to get her, they never told her anything about their being officers, but that she, knowing that she had run away from Frisco, naturally supposed they were officers; but that at any rate, she voluntarily came with them; she also says in this affidavit that Young and Sugiura told her on the boat they were going to take her back to the house in Frisco where she had formerly practiced prostitution. While the statements of Young and Miss Deadrich and Attorney Martin all show that she testified at the trial that she had no talk whatever with Young and Sugiura going down on the boat.

We cite these inconsistencies in evidence in order to show that while they have amounted to some evidence upon a charge of white slavery, of which Young and Sugiura were acquitted, hyet they do not amount to any evidence upon the charge in this Immigration proceeding.

The affidavit of Washio, upon which the Government bases its prinicipal defense in this Habeas Corpus, and which they especially set out in paragraph IV, of theier affirmative defense, though by an 8
admitted perjurer, and though bearing animosity against Young and Sugiura, admits that he came to Seattle in search of the woman, iwht a lie upon his lips about her being his wife; that he represented to the hotel-man with whom he stopped, to Young and Sugiura, to Okajima, anohter interpreter, and to Mr. Thayer, the detective, and others, that the woman was his wife, and that he had come to Seattle to get her. By ingratiating himself in Sugiura's confidence with recollections of old neighborhood and family ties back in Japan, it is not strange that Young and Sugiura believed him and were willing to assist him in the effort, as they thought, to regain his wife. On the last half of page of Washio's testimony, he testified as follows:

"Q How lond did you and Hana live together in San Francisco before she ran away from you? A About five months from January to about May, about four months, the 7th of May. Q Was that when she away the 7th of May? A Yes. Q It was your intention to make her your wife at that time wasn't it? A Yes. Q And you wrote back to Japan to the father for permission to marry her didn't you? A Yes. Q It wasn't your intention to put her into prostitution then when you came up here?: A My intention was to take her back and live with me as my wife but not put her in a house of prostitution. Q And you hired Sugiura and Young to help you get her with that idea and that intention didn't you? A I asked them to bring her to Seattle. Q Where did you and Hana live together in San Francisco before she ran away? A At 1020 Stockton Street."

While he intimates that he did tell Sugiura that she had formerly been a prostitute, yet all the evidence in the case tends to show that whatever she had been she was now reformed and it was Washio's intention, as well as her willingness, that she should go back to Frisco and live with him as his wife.

The testimony of Ito and Umeda show it was not Young and Sugiura who protected Hana from arrest, but another man, named Nakada, and they, as well as Hana, show that Young and Sugiura's 9
efforts with regard to the woman ended when they landed at the dock in San Francsico, because Ito and his wife took charge of Hana and she went with them, voluntarily to the house, 10120 Stockton Street, where she had formerly lived, and that Young and Sugiura merely followed along with the party, and Hana never saw them afterwards. This likewise, is the testimony of the other witness, Umeda.

An entire perusal of all the evidence in the record, so far as any of legal value or applicability goes, fails absolutely to show any act or effort on the part of Young and Sugiura, either to protect the woman from arrest, or to render her any other assistance, than a respectful aid which they were giving to Washio and her as his reputed wife.
Brief

Federal Courts will, On Habeas Corpus, look into the deportation recorded to determine whether or not there is any evidence therein to sustain the charge upon which the persons are sought to be deported.

U.S. vs. Williams 200 Fed. 541-2 (same) 189 " 917 Frick vs. Lewis 195 " 696 U.S. vs. Martin 193 " 797-8 Exparte Saraceno 182 " 957 Exparte Patterson 166 " 539 U.S. vs. Sibrary 176 " 149 Supra Bouve's Exclusion & Expulsion of Aliens pp. 519-545
In the caseof Frick vs. Lewis, 195 Federal, 696, the Court says:

"The court believed that there was no evidence tending to support any of the charges, except the one concerning the woman. Where there is nothing to support a charge, we agree that the department cannot rightfully issue a warrant to deport; for that would be a clear abuse of power."
In the case of ex parte Saraceno, 182 Ferderal, 957, the Court says:

"If there was any evidence competent or otherwise to sustain this finding, the Court, though of a different opinion, should not distrub it. But it is impossible to avoid the conclusion that the real ground for the order is that the immigration authorities think the alien an undesirable citizen, which is a class not excluded by the immigration law. The proof, as we have seen, is that the alien is not without funds, is young, healthy, following the trade 10 by which he has supported himself and his family for years in this country, and is going to his brother, who has lived here for years following the trade of tailor."
In the case of ex parte Patterson, 166 Federal, 539, the Court says:

"A preliminary question has been suggested which must first be considered: Has this Court authority in a habeas corpus case to examine the record of the proceedings before the immigrant inspector for the purpose of ascertaining whether the Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Labor, in issuing his warrant for deportation, acted with respect fo a matter over which he had jurisdiction? It is of couse well settled by abundant authority that the writ of habeas corpus cannot be employed to perform the function of a writ of error or an appeal. There are, however, several recent decisions of the Supreme Court holding that the courts of the United States have jurisdiction to grant relief to a party aggrieved by any action by the head or one of the subordinate officals of a department, when the evidence adduced before such official, and upon which he assumes to act, is wholly uncontradicted, and above beyond any room for dispute or doubt that the case in any view is beyond the statutes, and not covered or provided for by them. Gonzales v. Williams, 192 U.S. 1; 24 Sup. Ct. 177; 48 L. Ed. 317; American School of Magnetic Healing b. McAnnulty, 187 U.S. 94, 23 Sup. Ct. 33; 47 L. Ed. 90. Upon the authority of these cases - and many others might be cited there can be no room for question that this court has authority to examine the record and the evidence upon which the Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Labor predicated his authority to issue his warrant for the deportation of the petitioner, for the sole purpose of ascertaining whether the evidence before that official, and upon which he assumed to act, showed beyond any room for dispute or doubt that this case is beyond the purview of the immigration statutes of the United States, and not covered or provided for by them."
Persons sought to be deported are entitled to a full, fair hearing:
Chin Yow vs. U. S. 208 U. S. 11. Ex parte Long Lock, 173 Fed. 208.
The charge contained in the warrant of arrest and warrant of deportation must be reasonably specific: U. S. vs. Sibray, 178 Fed. 146. (see page 3 of this Brief)
